title: Ella Stern
text:
Hi, I’m Ella!
I’m a graduating senior at the George Washington University in Washington, DC. I like journalism, local politics and following cultural trends.
After graduation, I’m looking to pursue a career in strategic communications or public relations.

title: Portfolio

title: Portfolio
section: How public interest communicators can engage youth advocates to advance urgent causes
text:
How public interest communicators can engage youth advocates to advance urgent causes
This is a blog post I wrote during my internship at Spitfire Strategies in the summer of 2022. The blog focuses on how professionals in the field of public interest communications can best support youth advocates.

title: Portfolio
section: GW must provide students with the means to succeed this fall
text:
GW must provide students with the means to succeed this fall
This is an op-ed that I wrote during in fall 2020 urging GW administrators to support students throughout the period of online learning, from Fall 2020-Spring 2021.

title: Portfolio
section: The CROWN Act and It’s Impact on Black Color at GW
text:
The CROWN Act and It’s Impact on Black Color at GW
This is a news package that I made for Broadcast News Reporting in Spring 2021. The package featured coverage of the recently passed CROWN Act and input from the GW community on its significance.

title: Analysis Walkthrough Example
text:
Introduction
What data will you be working with?
A dataset of disbursements (payments and purchases) by the Donald J. Trump for President campaign committee during the 2020 election cycle. The included payments are from 2017 and 2018.
This data and examples were developed as part of the NYT Open training, which we’ve adapted from here. Note that the dataset has been alterted for instructional purposes, so doesn’t represent the original FEC data in its entirety.
In the environment tab in the upper right, click on the payments dataset to open the RStudio viewer to examine the data. You can also run the chunk below as well to bring up a slice of the data.


Code
head(payments)


# A tibble: 6 × 21
  committee_name         election_cycle report_year entity_type entity_type_desc
  <chr>                           <dbl>       <dbl> <chr>       <chr>           
1 DONALD J. TRUMP FOR P…           2020        2018 ORG         ORGANIZATION    
2 DONALD J. TRUMP FOR P…           2020        2018 ORG         ORGANIZATION    
3 DONALD J. TRUMP FOR P…           2020        2018 ORG         ORGANIZATION    
4 DONALD J. TRUMP FOR P…           2020        2018 ORG         ORGANIZATION    
5 DONALD J. TRUMP FOR P…           2020        2018 ORG         ORGANIZATION    
6 DONALD J. TRUMP FOR P…           2020        2018 ORG         ORGANIZATION    
# ℹ 16 more variables: recipient_name <chr>, recipient_state <chr>,
#   disbursement_description <chr>, disbursement_date <date>,
#   disbursement_month <dbl>, disbursement_year <dbl>,
#   disbursement_amount <dbl>, election_type <chr>,
#   fec_election_type_desc <chr>, amendment_indicator_desc <chr>,
#   payee_last_name <chr>, payee_first_name <chr>, payee_middle_name <chr>,
#   recipient_city <chr>, disbursement_purpose_category <chr>, pdf_url <chr>

title: Analysis Walkthrough Example
text:
Before you begin
Take a moment to look at the various categories included for each disbursement.

Notice that there are several date-related fields:

FEC election cycle
report year
election type
disbursement date

There are a few fields about the recipient. Along with city and state, you have:

the recipient name
the payee’s first and last name (an individual who was paid for the “recipient”) and
the entity type (individual v. organization)

title: Analysis Walkthrough Example
text:
Initial Narrative Questions
Without doing any analysis yet, what are three questions you might try to answer using this dataset? Write your narrative answers in the spaces below.

In what year did the campaign make the most contributions?
What entity type did they contribute the most to - individual or organization?
What state recieved the greatest contributions on average?

title: Analysis Walkthrough Example
text:
Coding Assignment Questions
Please write your R tidyverse code to help answer the questions below in the provided R chunks. You can make more than one chunk if you prefer.
Also, describe what you’re doing either in text out “in the open” above the chunk, or in comments (prefaced by #) in the R chunk itself.
You’ll need to use grouping, filtering, or a combination of both to find the answers. Remember that R is case-sensitive when you refer to any text values within the columns

How much was spent in the 2017 vs. 2018 reporting year?


Code
payments %>% 
  group_by(disbursement_year) %>% 
  summarise(totalspent = sum(disbursement_amount)) 


# A tibble: 2 × 2
  disbursement_year totalspent
              <dbl>      <dbl>
1              2017  17082338.
2              2018  37212716.


Code
## since there is only 2017 and 2018 data i grouped by the code for disbursement year and found the sum total for amount spent


Tally the total overall disbursement amounts for each month (distinguishing between say, Oct. 2018 v. Oct. 2019). In which month was spending the highest?


Code
payments %>% 
  group_by(disbursement_month, disbursement_year) %>% 
  summarise(totalspent = sum(disbursement_amount)) %>% arrange(desc(totalspent)) 


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'disbursement_month'. You can override
using the `.groups` argument.


# A tibble: 24 × 3
# Groups:   disbursement_month [12]
   disbursement_month disbursement_year totalspent
                <dbl>             <dbl>      <dbl>
 1                 10              2018   9738568.
 2                 11              2018   7965133.
 3                 12              2018   3599035.
 4                  7              2018   2995762.
 5                  9              2018   2610151.
 6                  8              2018   2374412.
 7                  6              2017   2005105.
 8                  8              2017   1926848.
 9                  1              2017   1913251.
10                  2              2017   1728508.
# ℹ 14 more rows


Code
## in October 2018 the spending was the highest
## i first grouped by the month and year (being 2017 and 2018) then found the total amout spent and used the arrange(desc) command to order them highest to lowest


Which recipient (recipient_name) was paid the most in the 2020 election cycle?


Code
payments %>% 
  group_by(recipient_name) %>% 
  filter(election_cycle == 2020) %>% 
  summarise(totalrec = sum(disbursement_amount)) %>% 
  arrange(desc(totalrec)) %>% top_n(1)


Selecting by totalrec


# A tibble: 1 × 2
  recipient_name                       totalrec
  <chr>                                   <dbl>
1 AMERICAN MADE MEDIA CONSULTANTS, LLC 9772584.


Code
## i filtered by the 2020 election cycle and summarised for the total amount received in ascending order 


Look at what this recipient was paid for. What service or good (see the “disbursement_description”) were they paid the most for?


Code
payments %>% 
  filter(recipient_name == "AMERICAN MADE MEDIA CONSULTANTS, LLC") %>% 
  group_by(disbursement_description) %>% 
  summarise(total = sum(disbursement_amount)) %>% 
  arrange(desc(total))


# A tibble: 9 × 2
  disbursement_description                   total
  <chr>                                      <dbl>
1 PLACED MEDIA                            4334158.
2 ONLINE ADVERTISING                      3650155.
3 ONLINE ADVERTISING & SUBSCRIPTIONS      1222606.
4 SUBSCRIPTIONS                            258126.
5 VIDEO PRODUCTION SERVICES                166748.
6 DIGITAL CONSULTING/ONLINE ADVERTISING     75000 
7 DIGITAL CONSULTING & ONLINE ADVERTISING   30095 
8 DIGITAL CONSULTING                        20834.
9 RESEARCH CONSULTING                       14862.


Code
# i filtered recipient for the recipient that recieved the most amount in 2020. Then I grouped by description and summed the disbursement amount for each description and arranged in descending order.


What’s the most common category overall (see “disbursement_description”) the campaign spent money on?


Code
### fix this ###
payments %>% 
  group_by(disbursement_description) %>% 
  summarise(count = n()) %>% 
  arrange(desc(count))


# A tibble: 732 × 2
   disbursement_description                               count
   <chr>                                                  <int>
 1 MERCHANT FEES                                           1002
 2 PAYROLL                                                  439
 3 EVENT CONSULTING                                         312
 4 AMEX PMT [SB23.1401808]: TRAVEL: GROUND TRANSPORTATION   242
 5 AMEX PMT [SB23.4150]: TRAVEL: AIR                        212
 6 AMEX PMT [SB23.4150]: TRAVEL: GROUND TRANSPORTATION      203
 7 AMEX PMT [SB23.1405358]: TRAVEL: GROUND TRANSPORTATION   202
 8 AMEX PMT [SB23.4150]: TRAVEL: INSURANCE                  193
 9 AMEX PMT [SB23.4150]: TRAVEL: LODGING                    177
10 AMEX PMT [SB23.4148]: TRAVEL: GROUND TRANSPORTATION      170
# ℹ 722 more rows


Code
## the campaign spent the most common categroy was merchant fees


Who were the 5 biggest recipients of campaign spending on “LEGAL CONSULTING”..?


Code
payments %>% 
  group_by(recipient_name) %>% 
  filter(disbursement_description == "LEGAL CONSULTING") %>% 
  summarise(total = sum(disbursement_amount)) %>% 
  arrange(desc(total)) %>% top_n(5)


Selecting by total


# A tibble: 5 × 2
  recipient_name                                total
  <chr>                                         <dbl>
1 JONES DAY                                  4390352.
2 LAROCCA HORNIK ROSEN GREENBERG & BLAHA LLP  404774.
3 KASOWITZ, BENSON, TORRESS & FRIEDMAN        322614.
4 THE LAW OFFICES OF ALAN S. FUTERFAS         287924 
5 MCDERMOTT WILL & EMERY                      276278.


Code
## i used the code from above but filtered only for this recipient. then i arranged using the function top_n which i found from the tidyverse encyclopedia online


Who are the top 5 individuals (vs. organization) were paid by the campaign committee?


Code
payments %>% 
  group_by(recipient_name) %>% 
  filter(entity_type == "IND") %>% 
  summarise(total = sum(disbursement_amount)) %>% 
  arrange(desc(total)) %>% top_n(5)


Selecting by total


# A tibble: 5 × 2
  recipient_name       total
  <chr>                <dbl>
1 GLASSNER, MICHAEL  511280 
2 DOLLMAN, SEAN      389541.
3 CENTINELLO, DARREN 214934.
4 CARR, CHRISTOPHER  160000 
5 PENCE, JOHN        104244.


Code
## i used the same code as above but filtered for the entity type of individuals


For the indvidual who was paid the most, which payment category (disbursement_description) was the top one for him or her? And how much money were they paid in that category?
payments %>% group_by(disbursement_description) %>% filter(recipient_name == “GLASSNER, MICHAEL”) %>% summarize(total = sum(disbursement_amount)) %>% arrange(desc(total)) %>% top_n(1)

title: Analysis Walkthrough Example
section: i filtered for michael and found the total amount he was paid, i arranged for only the top amount through the command top_n(1)
text: i filtered for michael and found the total amount he was paid, i arranged for only the top amount through the command top_n(1)
